data: Fit in die Zukunft durch ein Auslandspraktikum

“FfF- Fit for future through an internship abroad” is the title of the project of the HLW Perg 2017.
20 students are curious to see Europe. They don´t want to be restricted in their thinking and conquer Europe as ambassadors of the HLW Perg. The project initiative Erasmusplus supports the mobility within the European Union.

In the summer 2017, 20 students of the HLW Perg are going to complete their internship for three months in Spain, France, the United Kingdom and Germany in the period from June 1st until September 30th.
15 students chose France, Spain and the United Kingdom as their target countries to improve their language skills in French, Spanish and English. 
5 students chose Germany for their internship. Their primary motive is the mobility within and for Europe.  The five students are not ready to do their internship in a foreign speaking country yet.

For 20 students the third school year ends on May 31st, 2017 and the following school year starts on October 2nd, 2017. 

In the curriculum of the five years of education at the HLW it is written, that a compulsory internship with a minimum duration of three months between the third and fourth school year is part of the school education. The internship may be completed in an economic and administration business, but preferably in hotel and gastronomy businesses. According to § 34a of the Vocational Training Act, many professional and training qualifications are connected to the school education after finishing the final exams. The proof of a three-month internship in the sectors hotel business and gastronomy and the associated organizational departments (kitchen, restaurant, bar, reception and catering) enable job-related advantages and clear the way for independency.

Targets and expected results of an internship abroad:
• Living and working in another country for three months.
• Application and extension of the eight key competences and of the knowledges and skills acquired in school
• Improvement of opportunities on the national, European and international labor market.
The district of Perg is characterized by the settlement of many international economic businesses, such as Habau, Engel, Hödlmayr, …
• Promotion of mobility and flexibility
• Strengthening life skills, personality and independency
• Development in self-determination and personal responsibility
• Increased acceptance of challenges such as working and living in an intercultural environment
• Improvement of language skills and communication in English, Spanish and French
• New friendships
• Expansion of personal horizon and getting to know other organization and cultures, business organizations and work flows

Let's Leap Ahead (LLA) is a project which aims to provide new learning and knowledge exchange opportunities for youth workers who support Looked After Children (children living in residential care) and those in transition or leaving care in Europe.

The project provides opportunities for youth worker professionals from the UK and Germany to learn from each other to improve our support for our most vulnerable young people.  The European Social Pedagogy model will be the approach that will be studied, both academically and in practice.  This model has been proven to improve young people's outcomes, particularly those who live in the care system.  

The project will offer:

- new professional opportunities to understand, learn and share best European Social Pedagogy working practices, across a range of European settings;
- improved working practices in youth work settings across the UK and Germany;
- networking and job shadowing opportunities for youth workers; and
- opportunities for young people in the UK and German care systems, to share their experiences with the visiting professionals.

The anticipated project impact will be that all the participants will improve their theoretical and practical skills in Social Pedagogy, in relation to supporting Europe's most vulnerable young people.  This will enable the sharing of the best practice and will contribute to the transformation of the way we support children and young people living in care.  This will provide them with a much brighter future with vastly improved life outcomes. 

Break and Elisabethheim Havetoft have been partners since 2009, since a Norfolk County Council social pedagogy research visit took place.  Since this time both youth exchanges and professional visits have occurred and plans to share best practice been developed.  

This project forms part of a wider strategic project development in the area of European Social Pedagogy practice in relation to supporting children, young people in the care system, and young adults transitioning out of care.  The longer term benefits of this project is in relation to national policy and the provision of care and support, for vulnerable young people and their families, which may be transformed in the future.  This has wider positive implications for the whole of society as our most vulnerable citizens are supported to take advantage of all the opportunities that Europe has to offer.

Way To Go! (WTG!) is a project which aims to provide new and exciting learning opportunities for young people living in residential care and in transition or leaving care.

The project provides youth exchanges between 24 young people living in care in East Anglia, in Break charity's children's homes, and young people living in care in Northern Germany, at Elisabethheim Havetoft.  The exchanges will offer a range of activities to: provide the young people with experience living in new environments; develop their skills and expand their horizons; and improve their European citizen and cultural awareness.

The young people taking part in the project have very high levels of need.  They all come from difficult and challenging home lives (most having experienced abuse, and parental mental health and drug and alcohol issues).  All of them have Special Educational Needs: either in terms of learning difficulties and/or disability, or in terms of mental health or behavioural disorders.

There will also be staff exchanges for 4 youth workers at Break and Elisabethheim Havetoft, to enable them to share social pedagogy best practice and so that they can learn from the different approaches in supporting extremely vulnerable young people at each Centre.

The project impact anticipated is that all the young participants will improve their skills in areas such as communication, sense of initiative, and cultural and European awareness.  This will provide the young people with invaluable experience that they can bring back and apply to themselves in their home environments.  Staff undergoing exchanges will also be able to exchange their professional skills and then apply this new knowledge to their work environments on their return.

Break and Elisabethheim Havetoft have been partners since 2009, since a Norfolk County Council social pedagogy research visit took place.  Since this time both youth exchanges and professional visits have occurred and plans to share best practice been developed.  

This project forms part of a wider development in the area of social pedagogy practice in relation to supporting children, young people in the care system, and young adults transitioning out of care.
